title.value: Augmenting Human Selves Through Artificial Agents – Lessons From the Brain
title.justification: The title provides a clear indication that the paper discusses augmentation of human selves through artificial agents, taking inspiration from the brain.
title.quote: Augmenting Human Selves Through Artificial Agents – Lessons From the Brain.

extractions.description: This paper explores how artificial agents can augment human cognitive capacities by mimicking brain processes. It emphasizes the integration of the free energy principle (FEP) with temporo-spatial dynamics (TSD) for adaptive intelligence augmentation. These insights are applied to various applications, such as psychiatric self-regulation and disaster prediction.

type.justification: The paper develops theoretical models based on principles from neuroscience to propose a new class of artificial agents.
type.quote: We propose a novel AI approach. Rather than creating human intelligence, we propose augmenting it. For that purpose, we suggest taking lessons from the brain as a key strategy in attempts to build artificial agents that can support and augment human selves.

name.justification: The primary focus is on augmenting human intelligence through artificial means, a core aspect of AI.
name.quote: Much of current artificial intelligence (AI) and the drive toward artificial general intelligence (AGI) focuses on developing machines for functional tasks that humans accomplish.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses neuro-mental processes and their augmentation through AI.
The ethical implications of augmenting human capacities through AI are an undercurrent throughout the paper.
name.quote: Centre for Research Ethics & Bioethics, Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden
